Subject: Cantera as a chemistry engine for a CFD code
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=261819936; y=5P2VFXm2r1X2Lj0gdIfThzb8TmfaF8PnYLJkqLp0ys73fiIqDPKt

Hello,

I have just installed and given a quick look through most of
the av=
ailable documentation. I think it is a good fit to my
problem, but I'd like=
 the opinion of other more experienced
users before I dive fully in.

I'm t=
hinking of using cantera as "chemistry engine" for a
CFD code I'm developin=
g. I'm mostly interested, at this time, on
phase equilibrium, but I'm *very=
* interested on adding chemical
reactions later on.

I intend to write most=
ly in python, with numpy (numarray
to stay compatible with cantera) using f=
inite differences.
The domains (and the number of cells) can be really big.=


Would you think cantera is appropriate for this?
If this does not sound t=
oo absurd, I have another question.

I haven't really looked at cantera's c=
ode yet, but I'm already
thinking how to adapt it to a CFD code.

The fist =
and obvious way is to work with arrays of Cantera
phases, ie, to store in e=
ach (of the many many thousands) cell
a cantera phase, and use it's own int=
ernal variables on each cell
to keep track of molar fractions, etc. This wo=
uld be _very_ neat,
but I'm afraid there could be too much overhead, since =
a lot of
the information would be replicated on all cells.

The other would=
 be to store everything myself, and just invoke
cantera passing the full th=
ermodynamical state to it. This looks kind
of gross, considering I'd be was=
ting a lot of the good thinking and
hard work Dr. Goodwin already applied t=
o this problem! In the end I'd
end up replicating most of the phases and fl=
uid classes (which I
already had started to do, before I decided to check t=
he internet,
just in case someone had had the same problem before, and here=
 I am).

Sorry for the long post, any comments or suggestions most welcome.=


Best regards,

Ramiro.
